awd_abstract_narration:
Why are there more languages that have suffixes than ones that have prefixes? Why do languages that have both prefixes and suffixes use the suffixes more? One explanation that has been suggested is that the beginnings of words are more salient and therefore more important Yet little research has been done on the relative ability of speakers to understand and produce prefixes in contrast to suffixes. Most prior research has been conducted on English; the little research on other languages is mostly on languages related to English, such as French or Spanish.

The goals of this collaborative research project are to analyze processing and production differences among clitics occurring in different positions, and to test whether any differences are the same cross-linguistically. The research targets a language that is unrelated to English and other Indo-European languages: Udi, a member of the Nakh-Daghestanian language family. It examines both affixes and the precursors of affixes, clitics. Clitics are little words that are pronounced with a host word, similar to the way English 'will' can be pronounced with the subject of a verb: he'll go. Udi is unusual in having clitics that can occur in four different positions in the verb: at the end of verbs, before the verbs, between meaningful parts of the verb, and inside the root of the verb. Psycholinguistic experiments will compare the perception/production of clitics in different positions, and compare clitics in one position with suffixes occurring in the same position. Further, the researchers will compare these aspects of Udi with the same aspects of European Portuguese, another language with both affixes and clitics that can occur in various positions. This research is significant because it will inform an interpretation of the human ability to understand words and will apply this interpretation to typological differences among languages and the historical change from clitics to affixes. Researchers will work with an Udi literacy expert and will create materials based on their research that will aid in literacy efforts.

por.por_cntn:
Why are there more languages that have suffixes than ones that have prefixes?  Why do languages that have both prefixes and suffixes use the suffixes more?  The classic explanation that has been suggested is that the beginnings of words are more salient and therefore more important (Cutler-Hawkins hypothesis). Prefixes, it is assumed, are of secondary importance in understanding words. Yet little research had been done on the relative ability of speakers to understand and produce prefixes in contrast to suffixes. Most of the research that had previously been completed was on English, with a little research on other languages, mostly on languages related to English, such as French.

In this research, led by Alice C. Harris at the University of Massachusetts Amherst and Arthur Samuel at Stony Brook University and the Basque Center for Cognition, Brain, and Language, the goal was to determine whether prefixes or suffixes are easier to understand and produce, and whether this is true across all languages. We tested the hypothesis, known as the Cutler-Hawkins hypothesis, that prefixes disrupt the comprehension of a word more than suffixes do.The project examined both affixes (i.e., prefixes and suffixes) and the precursors of affixes, clitics. Clitics are little words that are pronounced with a host word, similar to the way English will can be pronounced with the subject of a verb, e.g. he’ll go.The research targets two languages that are unrelated to English and other Indo-European languages, Georgian, a language of the Kartvelian family, and Udi, a member of the Nakh-Daghestanian language family. Georgian provides pairs of affixes with related meanings, such as v- meaning 'first person subject' and -s 'third person singular subject'. Another related pair tested is i- and -d, which, together with other affixes, form intransitive verbs from transitive ones. One experiment was also done on English affixes, for comparison with Georgian. Udi is unusual in having clitics that occur in four different positions in the verb: at the end of verbs, before the verbs, between meaningful parts of the verb, and inside the root of the verb. Portuguese, with clitics occurring in the first three of those positions, provides a comparison with Udi. Experiments on Georgian and English compared understanding and production of prefixes and suffixes to see whether one position is easier to comprehend and produce than another position. Experiments on Udi and Portuguese compared the understanding and production of clitics in the four or three positions to determine whether one was relatively easier. A second hypothesis was tested for clitics, namely that clitics inside the word would be more difficult to understand (comprehended more slowly and less accurately).

The experiments on affixes (English and Georgian) found little support for the Cutler-Hawkins hypothesis. We conducted a number of tests, and some provided slight support for the hypothesis. But taken as a whole, the hypothesis was not supported. Generally, the experiments with Udi and Portuguese clitics also failed to support the idea. More precisely, across the various experiments and measures, there were at least as many cases in which the observed pattern was at odds with the predictions of the processing account as cases that were consistent with it. In one set of experiments, in both languages, clitics preceding the verb were processed faster than those that followed it (consistent with the hypothesis), but clitics inside the verb were faster than those outside it (thus overall inconsistent with the hypothesis). We suggest that an alternate explanation is needed for the fact that suffixes are more widely used than prefixes.

 

Broader Impact

We had a brochure on the topic of this research prepared by an outside agency, which distributes such brochures to high school students.
